stories.title: AbsenceBench: Language models can't tell what's missing
stories.author: JnBrymn
stories.article_summary: The article "AbsenceBench: Language Models Can't Tell What's Missing," authored by Harvey Yiyun Fu and five others, introduces a new benchmark for evaluating large language models (LLMs) on their ability to detect missing information in texts. Despite achieving a 69.6% F1-score on the AbsenceBench tasks with an average context length of 5,000 tokens, even state-of-the-art models like Claude-3.7-Sonnet struggle significantly due to the limitations of Transformer attention mechanisms in recognizing "gaps" in documents. The benchmark tests LLMs across three domains: numerical sequences, poetry, and GitHub pull requests, highlighting a critical distinction between tasks where models excel (e.g., Needle in a Haystack) and those where they falter. The research underscores the need for improved model architectures to better handle information omissions.

agreement_points: The community agrees on the effectiveness of data augmentation, as evidenced by historical practices dating back to the AlexNet paper, which established foundational techniques for improving model performance.
disagreement_points: There is a debate on the relevance of certain augmentation techniques, such as rotation, with some arguing it may not be as beneficial for models expected to interpret text.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion reflects a strong consensus on the importance of data augmentation in AI training, with historical references to foundational techniques like those in the AlexNet paper. While there are debates regarding the effectiveness of certain methods, the overall sentiment emphasizes the necessity of diverse training data to enhance model robustness and performance.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter highlights a limitation in AI's image recognition capabilities, noting that while it successfully identified a Kanizsa triangle in one orientation, it failed to recognize the same image when rotated, demonstrating challenges in understanding abstract visual concepts.

specific_numbers: The mention of rotating images in training data highlights the importance of data augmentation techniques, which can significantly improve model performance by increasing the diversity of training samples.
tools_mentioned: Claude is discussed as an AI tool that can analyze images, showcasing its capabilities in image recognition and summarization, which is crucial for understanding how AI interprets visual data.
performance_data: The discussion on data augmentation techniques like rotation and flipping suggests that models trained with these methods can generalize better, improving their accuracy and robustness in real-world applications.

resource_requirements: The need for diverse training data is emphasized, as lacking this can lead to overfitting, where models perform well on training data but poorly on unseen data.
efficiency_gains: Using data augmentation methods like rotation can lead to significant efficiency gains in training, as it allows for more effective use of existing datasets without the need for additional data collection.

setup_instructions: Implementing data augmentation techniques is essential for training neural networks effectively; skipping this step can result in models that do not generalize well.

strong_agreements: The community agrees on the effectiveness of data augmentation, as evidenced by historical practices dating back to the AlexNet paper, which established foundational techniques for improving model performance.
major_disagreements: There is a debate on the relevance of certain augmentation techniques, such as rotation, with some arguing it may not be as beneficial for models expected to interpret text.
expert_opinions: Experts in the field emphasize the importance of data augmentation in training neural networks, citing its role in enhancing model robustness and performance across various tasks.

market_trends: The trend towards using synthetic data and augmentation techniques reflects a growing recognition of their importance in AI model training, which can lead to competitive advantages in AI development.

working_setups: Successful implementations of data augmentation techniques have been shown to improve model accuracy and reduce overfitting, leading to better performance in real-world applications.

actionable_advice: Incorporate data augmentation techniques like rotation and flipping into training pipelines to enhance model generalization and performance.
what_to_avoid: Avoid neglecting data augmentation as it can lead to models that are not robust, resulting in poor performance on unseen data.
optimization_tips: Experiment with various augmentation techniques to find the optimal combination that improves model performance without introducing noise.

top_comments.author: birdfood
top_comments.text:
Perhaps related, after watching a talk by Gerald Sussman I loaded an image of the Kanizsa triangle into Claude and asked it a pretty vague question to see if it could “see” the inferred triangle. It recognised the image and went straight into giving me a summary about it. So I rotated the image 90 degrees and tried in a new conversation, it didn’t recognise the image and got the number of elements incorrect:
This image shows a minimalist, abstract geometric composition with several elements:
Four black shapes that appear to be partial circles or "Pac-Man" like forms, each with a wedge cut out, positioned in the four corners/quadrants of the image Two thin black triangular or arrow-like shapes - one pointing upward in the upper left area, and one pointing to the right in the center-right area All elements are arranged on a light gray or off-white background

top_comments.author: latentsea
top_comments.text: I guess they will now just rotate all the images in the training data 90 degrees too to fill this kind of gap.

top_comments.author: recursivecaveat
top_comments.text: Everything old is new again: in the Alexnet paper that kicked off the deep learning wave in 2012, they describe horizontally flipping every image as a cheap form of data augmentation. Though now that we expect models to actually read text that seems potentially counter-productive. Rotations are similar, in that you'd hope it would learn heuristics such as that the sky is almost always at the top.

top_comments.author: bonoboTP
top_comments.text: That's called data augmentation. It was common alredy before AlexNet. And it never stopped being common, it's still commonly done.

top_comments.author: latency-guy2
top_comments.text: At least from when I was still doing this kind of work, look angle/platform angle scatterer signal (radar) mattered more than rotation, but rotation was a simple way to get quite a bit more samples. It never stopped being relevant :)

top_comments.author: mirekrusin
top_comments.text:
That's how you train neural network with synthetic data so it extracts actual meaning.
That's how humans also learn ie. adding numbers. First there is naive memoization, followed by more examples until you get it.
LLM training seems to be falling into memoization trap because models are extremely good at it, orders of magnitude better than humans.
IMHO what is missing in training process is this feedback explaining wrong answer. What we're currently doing with training is leaving out this understanding as "exercise to the reader". We're feeding correct answers to specific, individual examples which promotes memoization.
What we should be doing in post training is ditch direct backpropagation on next token, instead let the model finish its wrong answer, append explanation why it's wrong and continue backpropagation for final answer - now with explanation in context to guide it to the right place in understanding.
What all of this means is that current models are largely underutilized and unnecessarily bloated, they contain way too much memoized information. Making model larger is easy, quick illusion of improvement. Models need to be squeezed more, more focus needs to go towards training flow itself.

top_comments.author: atwrk
top_comments.text:
> That's how humans also learn ie. adding numbers. First there is naive memoization, followed by more examples until you get it.
Just nitpicking here, but this isn't how humans learn numbers. They start at birth with competency up to about 3 or 5 and expand from that. So they can already work with quantities of varying size (i.e. they know which is more, the 4 apples on the left or the five on the right, and they also know what happens if I take one apple from the left and put it to the others on the right), and then they learn the numbers. So yes, they learn the numbers through memorization, but only the signs/symbols, not the numeric competency itself.

top_comments.author: mirekrusin
top_comments.text:
Turtles all the way down, things like meaning of "more" is also memoized ie initially as "I want more food" etc. then refined with time, ie. kid saying "he's more than me" is corrected by explaining that there needs to be some qualifier for measurable quantity ie. "he's more tall (taller) than me" or "he is more fast (faster) than me" etc.
Using different modalities (like images, videos, voice/sounds instead of pure text) is interesting as well as it helps completing the meaning, adds sense of time etc.
I don't think we're born with any concepts at all, it's all quite chaotic initially with consistent sensory inputs that we use to train/stabilise our neural network. Newborns for example don't even have concept of separation between "me and the environment around me", it's learned.

top_comments.author: littlestymaar
top_comments.text:
And it will work.
I just whish the people believing LLM can actually reason and generalize see that they don't.

top_comments.author: ben_w
top_comments.text:
If that was evidence current AI don't reason, then the Thatcher effect would be evidence that humans don't: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thatcher_effect
LLMs may or may not "reason", for certain definitions of the word (there are many), but this specific thing doesn't differentiate them from us.

Invest in data augmentation techniques to enhance training datasets.

stories.title: Plastic bag bans and fees reduce harmful bag litter on shorelines
stories.author: miles

agreement_points: There is a consensus that bans should target products with viable plastic-free alternatives, which emphasizes the need for sustainable options in consumer goods to reduce plastic waste.
disagreement_points: Debate exists around the effectiveness of plastic bag bans, with some arguing that they lead to increased plastic waste, as seen in comments about the switch to thicker plastic bags for trash, indicating a potential loophole in the legislation.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion reflects a strong concern about the environmental impact of plastic bags, particularly in light of California's ban on single-use bags, which has led to an increase in heavier reusable bags that may contribute to microplastic pollution. Community members express frustration over the ineffectiveness of current legislation, with some advocating for a more comprehensive approach that includes viable alternatives to plastic. The sentiment is mixed, with agreement on the need for change but disagreement on the effectiveness of current measures.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The study reveals an increase in plastic bags on beaches, highlighting a troubling trend where California's ban on single-use bags has led to the proliferation of heavier, "reusable" bags that contain significantly more plastic and take longer to biodegrade. This raises concerns about the effectiveness of current plastic waste policies.

specific_numbers: The increase of plastic bags as a fraction of beach waste indicates a growing environmental concern, particularly as California's ban on single-use plastic bags has led to a reliance on heavier reusable bags, which may contribute to more microplastics in the environment.

strong_agreements: There is a consensus that bans should target products with viable plastic-free alternatives, which emphasizes the need for sustainable options in consumer goods to reduce plastic waste.
major_disagreements: Debate exists around the effectiveness of plastic bag bans, with some arguing that they lead to increased plastic waste, as seen in comments about the switch to thicker plastic bags for trash, indicating a potential loophole in the legislation.

failed_attempts: The attempt to ban single-use plastic bags in California is viewed as a failure by some, as it has led to increased plastic waste in landfills, particularly with the switch to thicker reusable bags, which undermines the intended environmental benefits.

actionable_advice: Advocating for a complete ban on plastic bags and requiring paper alternatives could lead to a significant reduction in plastic waste, as seen in Portland's approach.
what_to_avoid: Avoid implementing bans without considering the full lifecycle of alternatives, as this can lead to unintended consequences such as increased landfill waste.

top_comments.author: hedora
top_comments.text:
The study finds that plastic bags as a fraction of the waste on beaches increased in all areas, so that’s bad.
A more concerning issue is the nature of the bags being thrown away. California banned “single use” plastic bags (which we used to reuse as trash bags for the bathroom or whatever) but lets you buy “reusable” ones for a few cents at the checkout counter. The reusable ones are much heavier and contain 10-100x more plastic, and take even longer to biodegrade.
The study counts “items”, not weight, and reports a 25-47% decrease.
Assuming California is the region that hit 47% (call it 50%), and the reusable bags are better than the best available (only 10x worse than pre-ban) that translates to a 5x increase in microplastics on the beach. I’d consider this a disaster, not a win.
This matches older studies, which measured total plastic content of landfill waste before and after plastic bag bans like California’s.
Those showed sharp increases in plastic waste too. The studies in question were in places that did not allow the reusable plastic ones that California forced the stores to switch to. Instead, the authors found that people switched from using the disposable bags as trash bags to using kitchen trash bags, which are ~100x worse. If only 1% of households were using disposable shopping bags for trash, and no one reused the new style bags, then the policies ended up breaking even. In practice, the policies increased total plastic waste, despite being better thought out than California’s newer ban.
I’m all for banning plastic bags, but the current bans target the most efficient use of plastic, increasing overall plastic production and waste. The bans should only target things that have plastic-free alternatives, or at least that have less plastic intensive alternatives.

top_comments.author: fmbb
top_comments.text:
> Assuming California is the region that hit 47% (call it 50%), and the reusable bags are better than the best available (only 10x worse than pre-ban) that translates to a 5x increase in microplastics on the beach. I’d consider this a disaster, not a win.
You are assuming that people are throwing away more reusable plastic bags. Are they?
Where I live (Sweden) the extra plastic bag fee introduced made people also buy more single use plastic bags in bulk which were cheaper and flimsier. If they are making up a larger part of the "items" counted, and not the reusable bags, then the win is even greater than a 25-47% decrease.
What reason do you have to believe people are throwing away the heavier, reusable bags at that rate? Do other bags not exist anywhere?

top_comments.author: hilbert42
top_comments.text:
"The bans should only target things that have plastic-free alternatives, or at least that have less plastic intensive alternatives."
There's also what I call junk plastic products. I'll illustrate with examples. Plastic products that aren't durable and have very short lifespans:
- Plastic storage bins and such that use so little plastic that they break when stacked thus become plastic waste long before they ought to.
- I bought three plastic buckets at the supermarket and the handles fell off two before I got them home. I nevertheless used them only to find that they soon cracked and leaked with normal domestic usage.
(BTW, there's an old galvanized bucket in our family that's well over 80 years old (it belonged to my grandmother), and it's still serviceable (the galvanizing is still intact and it's not rusty).)
- The use of polyethylene for containers, etc. Over time polyethylene leaks its plasticizers to produce a greasy coating on the surface. The polyethylene then hardens and cracks—thus more junk plastic waste. Polyethylene should not be used for such purposes.
Moreover, phthalate plasticizers have been found to have bad effects on human health. Phthalate plasticizers ought to be banned for use in domestic products.
I could go on, there are hundreds more examples.
The plastic waste problem could be fixed quick smart if high taxes were applied on plastic products that were deemed insufficiently durable.
No doubt, manufacturers, penny-pinching cheapskates and greedy profit mongers would cry foul over what's deemed as 'durable'. That's solvable with standards set down by an authoritative standards body.

top_comments.author: socalgal2
top_comments.text:
100% agree though I'm curious how to fix things. If I go to any supermarket it's full of plastic. Of course many traditional products are often (not always) sold in plastic like milk, yogurt, cottage cheese, breads. But, stores are full of, packaged by the store or the store's company products. The easist place to see this is the prepared foods section. Veggie salads in plastic, pasta salad in plastic, hummus in plastic, cookies in plastic, nuts in plastic, sandwiches in plastic, ...
I have no idea what it would take to stop that and what the substitute would be. Examples: I like Japanese Milk Bread. It generally comes wrapped in a plastic bag, arguably because it's not hardy like something like sourdough which can be sold in an open paper bag.
Similarly, local markets sell Chinese sticky lotus leaf rice, 2 or 3 in a plastic container, they sell fresh tofu skin in a plastic container. I guess they could try to switch to waxed cardboard like milk is sometimes sold? Is that good or is that cardboard infused with plastic?
Has any "progressive" country banned plastic such that pre-sliced meat/cheese is not sold in plastic?

top_comments.author: dawnerd
top_comments.text:
I used the old style plastic bags as trash bags. I use the new thicker ones as trash bags (cat litter). All the law did was increase how much plastic ends up in the landfill.
They should have required paper. Oregon did the same dumb thing. Portland has paper bags everywhere. Then they required charging for bags and everyone switched to plastic.

top_comments.author: mjevans
top_comments.text:
My opinions:
* Leave my dang plastic straws alone or at least make any degradable replacement take longer than a week to degrade and __not crumple like a limp noodle__ during normal use.
* 1000% yes on this inanity of selling bags. Require standard grade carry out bags all be complimentary (this will drive stores to get the cheapest ones that don't irk customers), and just outright ban plastic for 'bags'. Do not specify exactly but require that any take out bag be (non commercially) compostable, or recycled (for real, not export to someone that just treats it as trash).

top_comments.author: Viliam1234
top_comments.text: My kids use silicon straws. You can take them apart, wash them, put them together again and they work ok.

top_comments.author: jlund-molfese
top_comments.text: Have you tried Phade? They’re pretty much the same as regular plastic straws, albeit slightly more brittle

top_comments.author: sfasdfh123
top_comments.text: I think people will be much better off not using straw in the first place. Unless you are constantly drinking soda,, which is not good for teeth anyway. If you have disability, then of course this not apply.

top_comments.author: cm2012
top_comments.text: Do you find a lot of success telling people how to live their lives?

stories.title: Captain Cook's missing ship found after sinking 250 years ago
stories.author: rmason
stories.article_summary: The wreck of Captain Cook's ship, HMS Endeavour, has been discovered off the coast of Rhode Island, where it sank 250 years ago during the American War of Independence. Identified as RI 2394, the ship was confirmed through a meticulous 25-year archaeological study by the Australian National Maritime Museum (ANMM), with measurements aligning closely to historical records, including "timbers that are almost identical to Endeavour, within millimeters," according to ANMM archaeologist Kieran Hosty. The ship, originally launched in 1768, was repurposed as a troop transport and scuttled to block Newport Harbour in 1778, and while artefacts are unlikely to be recovered, the findings emphasize the ship's unique features, such as its "stem scarf." The discovery follows a controversial preliminary report in 2022, which faced criticism from the Rhode Island Marine Archaeology Project (RIMAP) for being "premature."

disagreement_points: There is a debate regarding the identification of the wreck, with one comment highlighting that the Rhode Island Marine Archaeology Project disagreed with the identification, indicating a potential conflict in academic publication norms and the importance of consensus in historical discoveries.

Another comment suggests that the disagreement may stem from publication rights rather than the identification itself, emphasizing the complexities of academic publishing and the need for clarity in such discussions.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion reflects a mix of curiosity and skepticism regarding the identification of a shipwreck, with some commenters questioning the validity of the identification and others focusing on the implications of publication rights in academia. There is a notable interest in the wreck's location, with one user mentioning increased ship activity in Narragansett Bay, suggesting a community engagement with maritime history and archaeology.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter highlights a perceived delay by pointing out that the announcement in question was made three years prior, suggesting a lack of progress or follow-through since then.

major_disagreements: There is a debate regarding the identification of the wreck, with one comment highlighting that the Rhode Island Marine Archaeology Project disagreed with the identification, indicating a potential conflict in academic publication norms and the importance of consensus in historical discoveries.

Another comment suggests that the disagreement may stem from publication rights rather than the identification itself, emphasizing the complexities of academic publishing and the need for clarity in such discussions.

top_comments.author: cromulent
top_comments.text:
Didn't they announce this 3 years ago?
https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/feb/03/capta...

top_comments.author: hluska
top_comments.text: That article says that the Rhode Island Marine Archaeology Project didn’t agree with the identification. This new article is about a published article on the discovery. The articles are totally different.

top_comments.author: madaxe_again
top_comments.text: I read it not so much as a disagreement over identification but over publication rights, which is the norm in academia.

top_comments.author: CoastalCoder
top_comments.text:
Has anyone found a clear indication of the wreck's location?
There's been a lot of interesting ship activity in Narraganset Bay lately, at least as seen when crossing the Jamestown / Newport bridges. I'm curious if any of it's related to that wreck.

top_comments.author: duxup
top_comments.text: I'm sure the rename had good reason but I can't imagine going from a name like "HMS Endeavour", what a great name, to "Lord Sandwich" ... in modern times that sounds like some lighthearted forum username.

top_comments.author: linksnapzz
top_comments.text: The HMS Lord Sandwich's namesake is almost certainly former 1st Lord of the Admiralty John Montagu, the 4th Earl of Sandwich && person that the dish is actually named after.

top_comments.author: jonstewart
top_comments.text:
He was also head of the British navy ("First Lord of the Admiralty") at the time and a great supporter of Cook's, so there's even a closer connection specific to the Endeavor. Cook named Hawaii the "Sandwich Islands" after him.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Montagu,_4th_Earl_of_Sand...

top_comments.author: westurner
top_comments.text: What were the existing names of the islands?

top_comments.author: falcor84
top_comments.text: I love that they also marked up "Sandwich" as a tag, to make it easier for you to explore other articles they had published about sandwiches.

top_comments.author: bryanlarsen
top_comments.text: Same reason we get modern stupid names like "Crypto.com Arena". Those who pay the money and/or give the orders get to choose the name, and they like putting their own names on things.

stories.title: College baseball, venture capital, and the long maybe
stories.author: bcantrill
stories.article_summary: The article draws a compelling analogy between the experiences of college baseball players and the venture capital (VC) fundraising process, emphasizing the high stakes and emotional rollercoaster involved in both. The author, reflecting on his son's journey as a college athlete, notes that "the experience of the college athlete... looks uncannily like raising a round of venture capital." Key parallels include the importance of a "pitch deck," which for athletes consists of performance videos shared on platforms like Twitter, and the concept of the "Long Maybe," where both VCs and coaches often delay decisions, leading to uncertainty for the athlete or entrepreneur. The article highlights the non-binding nature of offers in college baseball, akin to VC term sheets, underscoring the necessity for athletes to assess the integrity of coaches—much like how investors evaluate VCs. Actionable insights include recognizing the importance of solid performance metrics and being wary of vague promises in both realms.

agreement_points: The community agrees that many career paths exhibit similar dynamics of success and failure, emphasizing the role of gatekeepers and market forces, which is important as it encourages a broader understanding of career trajectories beyond traditional views.
disagreement_points: There is debate on the value of pursuing careers with low chances of success, such as college sports, with some arguing that the experience gained can be valuable despite the low likelihood of professional advancement, indicating differing perspectives on risk and reward.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion reflects a nuanced understanding of how various career paths, particularly those in sports and entertainment, are influenced by power law dynamics and market forces. Participants highlight the importance of recognizing the role of gatekeepers and the potential for abuse in these fields. There is a consensus that while the chances of success may be low, the experiences gained can still hold value, prompting a debate on the worth of pursuing such paths.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter suggests that many careers, particularly those with financial outcomes following a power law, share similar dynamics of gatekeeping and relationships, often leading to experiences of rejection and the need for exceptional talent. They relate their own experience in venture capital to that of struggling artists, highlighting the common challenges faced across various fields.

specific_numbers: The concept of power law distributions in career outcomes suggests that a small percentage of individuals achieve the majority of success, which is significant because it highlights the inherent inequality in fields like sports and entertainment, impacting career choices and investments in these paths.

strong_agreements: The community agrees that many career paths exhibit similar dynamics of success and failure, emphasizing the role of gatekeepers and market forces, which is important as it encourages a broader understanding of career trajectories beyond traditional views.
major_disagreements: There is debate on the value of pursuing careers with low chances of success, such as college sports, with some arguing that the experience gained can be valuable despite the low likelihood of professional advancement, indicating differing perspectives on risk and reward.

market_trends: The rise of modern mass media has led to increased competition among creative professionals, as it allows for widespread access to audiences, which is significant because it changes how talent is recognized and monetized, impacting business strategies in entertainment.

actionable_advice: Individuals considering careers in high-competition fields should weigh the risks and potential rewards carefully, as understanding the dynamics of power laws can inform better career decisions and expectations.

top_comments.author: zemvpferreira
top_comments.text:
I think you can extend this transposition across a lot more career paths: athletes, entrepreneurs, musicians, models, film directors, etc. Any career where the financial outcome can be described by a power law follows the same dynamics, has the same gatekeepers, who have the same abusive/sycophantic relationships to market participants.
When I was raising VC I related more to struggling artist than employed technologists. Being constantly rejected, needing to be seen as more gifted than the competition and the goddamn urgency to catch on fire yesterday were the same and we got along great even if we understood and cared nothing about each other's work.
People who are considering one of these paths have an opportunity to learn from folks who might not do what they do exactly, but have been in the same sort of system. To realise the relationships they're buying into, the price they'll need to pay for a shot at stardom and to think if it's really an experience they can afford.

top_comments.author: dclowd9901
top_comments.text:
Keep going. This isn't unique to basically anything. Theres an analogy here for practically any case where there is scarcity and some manner of investment.
That said, I think this article is wins on providing me a window into the college athlete's world. It's a space that I feel like rarely shows up in popular media, is ripe for abuse and the stakes are definitely very high. Very interesting read for that.

top_comments.author: ghaff
top_comments.text: There are definitely "tournament" activities that are more winners take all than others. The stakes are probably actually higher to the degree consequences are stumbling down a dead-end path for years. I'm actually not convinced playing a sport in college while realizing you're not going to make it to the pros is such a terrible thing. Presumably they got something out of it. And lots of people play sports in college or do a multitude of other things that may--or may not--provide huge professional benefit.

top_comments.author: lazyant
top_comments.text: yes, and my pet theory is that the power law for creative professions (and others like realtors) come from low barriers of entry.

top_comments.author: jowea
top_comments.text: I think it comes from modern mass media technology. If musician A is better than B there is little reason to listen to B, unless you live in 1600 and musician A works in the next town over.

top_comments.author: wslh
top_comments.text: Modern mass media cannot generally differentiate between A and B because there are zillions of indistinguishable musicians invading the attention of people with very different marketing capacities.

top_comments.author: ghaff
top_comments.text: There's probably some truth to that. You either have gatekeepers or a huge number of people just fail. (Even with gatekeepers a lot of people just fail anyway but but of people just don't get the opportunity to participate--which may or may not be efficient.)

top_comments.author: sandworm101
top_comments.text: I spoke to a guy once who made gun parts, rifle bits for specific military uses. Their industry is also describable with power laws but at a much slower pace. You toil away selling a handful of units to a narrow group of highly-regulated customers, sometimes for decades, until you get that call to demonstrate your products for someone big (ie the US army). If you win, the next order is for tens of thousands of units. You license/outsource your design for a hundred per unit and walk away with a steady income that will last generations.

top_comments.author: system7rocks
top_comments.text:
A profoundly wise and great article.
My son is a big kid and is playing high school football. It was not on our radar, so we have begun to navigate these kinds of questions. Like - do you want to play at the next level? What do you even need to do if you would like to? But also the realization of how much money is made off of these kids and how cruel and unforgiving it can be.

top_comments.author: mayoff
top_comments.text:
Have you heard of CTE?
https://www.bu.edu/articles/2017/cte-former-nfl-players/

story_metadata.title: College baseball, venture capital, and the long maybe
story_metadata.author: bcantrill
